article.title: Growth and Antifungal Resistance of the Pathogenic Yeast, Candida Albicans, in the Microgravity Environment of the International Space Station: An Aggregate of Multiple Flight Experiences
article.abstract: This report was designed to compare spaceflight-induced cellular and physiological adaptations of Candida albicans cultured in microgravity on the International Space Station across several payloads.

sections.introduction: Candida albicans (C. albicans) is a commensal fungus found throughout the human body in locations such as the mouth, gastrointestinal tract, vagina, and skin [1,2].
sections.methods: C. albicans (SC5314, American Type Culture Collection) was maintained as a frozen stock at −80 °C.
sections.results: Although each mission has different timing, the specifics of which change in real time based on the actual launch date and accompanying mission scenario, Table 1 summarizes our general experiences for each payload.
sections.discussion: As increasing numbers of people spend longer amounts of time in space, it is imperative to understand the physiological adaptations that humans may experience as well as the threats they may encounter.

article.insights_summary: Candida albicans had a slightly shorter generation time and higher growth propensity in microgravity as compared to terrestrial controls. Yeast demonstrated an increased resistance when challenged during spaceflight with the antifungal agent, amphotericin B.
article.acknowledgments: We are very grateful to a vast and dedicated team.
